examples: no amount of struggle availed Charles

verb.description: Use or take advantage of (an opportunity or available resource).
examples: you can avail discounts on food
students in the district avail of the free meal scheme in schools
he begged her to reconsider, but to no avail
calls to tech support have been of no avail
Latin was of little avail in the practical affairs of life

phrases: I would suggest that his flying start to war has availed him nothing but the intensified scorn of the nation.
I'm afraid that your skills, such as they are, will avail you nothing.
It withered my heart, he wrote in his diary, but his presence could avail her nothing now.
Climbing trees or diving into water will avail you nothing with a tiger.
my daughter did not avail herself of my advice
origin: Middle English: from obsolete vail be of use or value (apparently on the pattern of pairs such as amount, mount), from Old French valoir, from Latin valere be strong, be of value.
